author: sproul
content: I don't think that's the central debate, as (almost) everyone here agrees that censorship is bad for Ethereum. I think the key disagreement is whether we ship builder-api support _even if_ no non-censoring relays exist -- in the hope that some non-censoring relays appear, or that we may mitigate the danger of the existing relay by giving client devs some control over its use (rather than encouraging Flashbots or the staking pools to hack their own clients). IMO it's harm-minimisation with an option for improvement (ship builder support in clients) vs absolute intolerance (delete builder support from clients).

author: sky.cactus
content: My general belief is that the majority of proposers won't run non-stock software initially after the merge.  Given enough time, I think *eventually* we'll see more and more people willing to run non-stock software but that will take a while.  My hope is that if we refuse to launch builder API support until there exist non-censoring relays, we'll either see non-censoring relays show up to the party or we'll see PBS implemented with CR lists (or similar) before we see significant adoption of a non-stock validating software stack.

I think the primary point of disagreement is:
1. How bad is the problems of not having MEV-Boost.
2. How long will it take for an unsupported MEV-Boost alternative to bootstrap without support from core client devs.

author: monkeyontheloose.eth
content: doesn't the block difficulty fix this?

author: sky.cactus
content: Block difficulty just makes it so the timestamps on blocks show up *approximately* X distance apart.  The difficulty algorithm will adjust automatically though, so if you fork away and then mine with some tiny fraction of hashpower for a while, the difficulty will adjust way down, then you'll be back to publishing blocks every ~13 seconds.  Once you are, you can then maintain pace with the main chain, and then right at the end crank up your hashpower to publish a large number of blocks in a row to catch up and surpass the block number of the main chain.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would take a bit of planning to figure out the ideal numbers to execute this attack, but my understanding is that there is nothing about the difficulty algorithm that prevents it.

author: postcapone
content:
I believe this might have some naivety to it

Consider the realitites that surround DeFi in the ETHPoW fork

It is painfully obvious that DeFi breaks in ETHPoW for a large number of reasons, but one of the more absolute and unreconcilable is stable coins.  Any stable coin backed by off-chain collateral goes to instant 0 cause you can't dupe the collat.  Anything backed by on-chain collat still breaks cause the collat ratio blows up (crazy to think that the ETHPoW fork will maintain enough value to support the collat ratio).

Coinbase and Lido alone represent enough of the Validator Set that the majority of "good" validators will have to initiate a soft fork to break away from them.

USDT and USDC following a fork that does not comply with the laws seems pretty unlikely.  So if Coinbase and Lido continue on the fork where their funds have not been slashed, then it seems pretty reasonable to think that USDT and USDC will support those chains.

The community will almost certainly be extremely divided here. The market could even go so far as to take something like a 50/50 split on the matter.  This would mean that on chain collateral in both chains could break (since the value of the collateral settles at prices below the necessary ratios in both chains).


*Hey guys, thanks for having me, look forward to conversations about this stuff.  I think that most of the conversation surrounding the merge and the current censorship issue hasn't really played out in public conversation yet, and hope that Ethereum can find good solutions now.

<@301186049323958275> <@77492786336636928> <@340345049063882753> <@361447803194441738> - I'm trying to squeeze reading the messages from the past 12 hrs into my work day, so for now let me give you bloXroute's high level, which ill likely make you feel a bit better:

- we *intend* to provide multiple choices to validators, allowing them to choose whether they want to maximize profit, avoid front-running, or avoid specific (e.g. OFAC) addresses.

- We don't think it's our role to choose for validators which Tx to include (as a block-builder), or which blocks to accept (as a relay), and we take no active part in interacting with these addresses.
we only help validators to construct blocks efficiently based on their requirements, leaving it for them to propose and attest

- while the max-profit and avoid-frontrunning options are ready for the merge, providing OFAC-compliant might not be (which is probably ok for all of you üòÑ )

- like everyone else, we ARE still processing the legal implications, so that's our *intention*. We're more than glad to collaborate with any EL and CL dev teams & validator, and keep everyone updated where we stand (feel free to DM me, I'll likely miss a @mention)

hope this helps üôè  I'll go online again in a few hours to try to catch up with the conversation, or answer if anyone has specific Qs

author: kudeta
content: I read the conversations above and understand and support the general sentiment. However, it seems like it‚Äôs a bit late to seriously consider removing builder APIs from clients. The timing is one thing, but more importantly the cat is truly out the bag given the code is written and tested, so any large staking operation will likely have the resources (and financial motivation) to simply rebase it right back in, enhancing profitability and driving further economic centralisation of staking in the longer term. While on the other hand leaving the APIs in might feel like you are supporting censorship, the reality is that PoW miners and searchers in general have always had the ability to selectively censor, should they chose to do so. At this stage I‚Äôd rather see a heavily resourced alternative relay project formed, combined with some aggressive community mobilisation to highlight the dangers and move people away from flashbots‚Äô relays. Finally, while a UASF  is a good threat to dangle, in the cold light of day slashing many thousands of ordinary ETH holders staking at Coinbase, Kraken etc (if they chose to censor) would be incredibly divisive, until these holders had at the very least been given plenty of time to exit (which I assume means post Shanghai).

author: slodkokwasny.
content: It's probably good to include bloXroute relay as the default for eth clients to counter the already established position of flashbots. Bloxroute was tested in one of the goerli shadows forks so it shouldn't be a technical problem. If clients launch with Builder API, it's better to promote a non-censoring relay than make people stick with more known Flashbots.

author: protoplanetary
content: Speaking as a solo staker, PBS is obviously necessary to prevent centralizing effects at the block proposer level, MEV-boost is obviously the best first step at implementing it, and I plan to run it *if and when* there are at least two independent relays available that verifiably (according to relay monitoring) do not censor, which are the only relays I will personally consider using. I understand that some parties may feel compelled to use censoring relays, and do not blame MEV-boost for the existence of such relays, although I'll strongly encourage all stakers to avoid them. Just my two gwei üôÇ

author: ajsutton
content: Clients are not including any relay or builder by default. They'll all use the local EL by default which is the most decentralised option. It will be up to the community to pressure setup guides, staking pools and users generally to choose "good" relays.
